question: If the shaft is subjected to an axial force of 5 kN, determine the bearing stress acting on the collar A. <image 1>
description:
The image depicts a mechanical assembly involving a shaft and a collar labeled "A." The shaft has a diameter of 60 mm and extends horizontally. At one end, it is subjected to an axial force of 5 kN, indicated by an arrow pointing towards the right. The shaft passes through a collar "A," which is positioned at a distance of 100 mm from the point where the force is applied.

The collar "A" has a thickness of 2.5 mm and is in contact with a supporting surface below it. The supporting surface has a rectangular shape with a width of 15 mm and a height of 2.5 mm. The collar "A" is also in contact with another part of the assembly above it, but this part is not relevant for calculating the bearing stress.

To determine the bearing stress acting on the collar "A," we need to consider the area over which the force is distributed. The bearing stress (σ_b) is given by the formula:

\[ \sigma_b = \frac{F}{A} \]

where \( F \) is the axial force and \( A \) is the bearing area. The bearing area \( A \) is the product of the thickness of the collar and the width of the supporting surface:

\[ A = \text{thickness of collar} \times \text{width of supporting surface} \]
\[ A = 2.5 \, \text{mm} \times 15 \, \text{mm} \]
\[ A = 37.5 \, \text{mm}^2 \]
\[ A = 37.5 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m}^2 \]

Now, substituting the values into the bearing stress formula:

\[ \sigma_b = \frac{5000 \, \text{N}}{37.5 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{m}^2} \]
\[ \sigma_b = \frac{5000}{37.5 \times 10^{-6}} \]
\[ \sigma_b = \frac{5000}{37.5 \times 10^{-6}} \]
\[ \sigma_b = 133.33 \times 10^6 \, \text{Pa} \]
\[ \sigma_b = 1.33 \, \text{MPa} \]
